challenge.description: The ordered structural model with lithium in tetrahedral 8a site and manganese and titanium in octahedral 16d site did not give satisfactory results for x ≥ 0.5.
challenge.impact: The inability to accurately model the cationic distribution affects the understanding of the material's structural properties and its potential applications.

solution.description: Introduced disorder in the cationic distribution to account for the observed electron density in the 8a and 16d sites.
solution.methodology: Refined structural models considering partial occupancy of Mn2+ in the 8a site alongside Li and Ti4+.
solution.effectiveness: The new model (Model 2) provided better agreement with bond valence sums and experimental data, though it contradicted previous XPS results.

evidence.source: Results and Discussion section, Table 1 and Table 3
evidence.data: Comparison of calculated bond valence sums (CBV) and expected bond valence sums (EBV) for Model 1 and Model 2.

context.material_properties: Spinel structure with cationic distribution affecting unit-cell parameters and magnetic properties.
context.experimental_conditions: Structural refinement using X-ray diffraction and neutron diffraction data.
context.application_relevance: Accurate structural modeling is critical for understanding the material's behavior in battery applications.

challenge.description: Substitution by non-magnetic d0 Ti4+ ions weakens the magnetic interactions between manganese ions.
challenge.impact: Weakening of magnetic interactions reduces the material's magnetic moment and affects its performance in applications requiring strong magnetic properties.

solution.description: Studied the temperature and magnetic field dependencies of magnetization to understand the impact of Ti substitution.
solution.methodology: Measured Field Cooled (FC) and Zero Field Cooled (ZFC) magnetization curves and fitted data using Curie–Weiss law.
solution.effectiveness: Confirmed the weakening of local antiferromagnetic interactions due to dilution of the Mn–O network by Ti4+ cations.

evidence.data: Curie constant (C) and Weiss constant (θ) values decrease with increasing Ti content.

context.material_properties: Spinel structure with magnetic properties influenced by cationic substitution.
context.experimental_conditions: Magnetization measurements performed between 5 and 350 K under μ0HDC = 0.1 T.
context.application_relevance: Understanding magnetic behavior is essential for optimizing the material for specific applications, such as solid-state batteries.

challenge.description: Solid-state synthesis resulted in high porosity and poor connectivity between well-sintered agglomerates.
challenge.impact: High porosity and poor connectivity negatively affect the material's electrical conductivity and overall performance.

solution.description: Used the Pechini method to prepare denser samples with better connectivity.
solution.methodology: Synthesized samples using a precursor gel method involving citric acid and ethylene glycol, followed by calcination and sintering.
solution.effectiveness: Pechini samples displayed lower porosity (18% vs. 30%) and better electrical conductivity compared to solid-state samples.

evidence.source: Results and Discussion section, Figure 5 and Figure 6
evidence.data: Electron micrographs and porosity measurements confirmed improved microstructure for Pechini samples.

context.material_properties: Spinel structure with electrical properties influenced by microstructure.
context.experimental_conditions: Comparison of samples prepared by solid-state reaction and Pechini method.
context.application_relevance: Improved microstructure enhances electrical conductivity, which is critical for battery applications.
